title: 111_hr476
content: The Act titled "Veterans, Women, Families with Children, and Persons With Disabilities Housing Fairness Act of 2010" allows for testing for discrimination. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is required to conduct a nationwide program to detect and document discriminatory practices in housing and mortgage lending markets based on race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability status, or national origin. The program will be administered through agreements with fair housing enforcement organizations, and the Secretary must submit an evaluation of the program's effectiveness to Congress. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must issue regulations for program applications to include descriptions of proposed activities, applicant experience, and evaluation procedures. Biennial reports to Congress on testing outcomes and recommendations, along with annual summaries of messages, are required. The Secretary must provide annual summaries of messages received by the Office of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity. Results from testing can be used to initiate investigations or enforcement actions against discriminatory housing practices. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of the Act to establish minimum standards for training testers conducting required testing. This training will be used to evaluate testers uncovering discriminatory housing practices. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will establish regulations for evaluating testers uncovering discriminatory housing practices. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 to carry out these provisions. Increase in funding for the Fair Housing Initiatives Program to $15,000,000 for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize $42,500,000 for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 for fair housing enforcement organizations, with specific allocations for private enforcement initiatives and education/outreach programs. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize $42,500,000 for fair housing enforcement organizations for program activities. Amounts appropriated under this section remain available until expended. Amendments include criteria for meeting subparagraphs (A) and (C), and expanding provisions to include websites and other media outlets. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize $42,500,000 for fair housing enforcement organizations for program activities. Regulations establishing minimum standards for training testers of organizations funded with allocated amounts are to be issued within 180 days of enactment. The regulations will serve as the basis for evaluating testers and will undergo a public comment period before implementation. The Sense of Congress is for the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to comply with fair housing education and outreach programs, regulations for fair housing obligations, and requirements of the Fair Housing Act. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will implement a grant program to assist organizations in conducting studies on housing discrimination and segregation, as well as implementing pilot projects to address these issues. Organizations must apply and provide matching funds to be eligible for the grants. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will require organizations to provide matching funds for grants, meet fair housing enforcement organization requirements, and submit biennial reports on study results and recommendations to Congress. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2011-2015 under the Fair Housing Act and Housing and Community Development Act of 1987. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS: Prohibits the use of funds for political activities, advocacy, lobbying, travel for political activities, or tax return advice.
